content.title: THE CLIMATE, ENVIRONMENTAL AND HEALTH BENEFITS OF SUSTAINABLE ENERGY
content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1

content.text: Lesson 1 Overview

Renewable energy is often linked to its ability to generate electricity with minimal greenhouse gas (GHG) emissions. This is a crucial factor in the global effort to mitigate climate change. As the climate crisis intensifies, renewable energy’s role in reducing emissions becomes even more vital. It plays a key part in achieving climate targets. This was highlighted at COP28, where countries agreed to triple global renewable energy capacity by 2030. This commitment aligns with the actions needed to meet global climate goals.

content.title: Key Concepts
content.intro: Explore foundational ideas from this lesson.

concepts.title: energy and air quality
concepts.body: Energy and air quality refer to the relationship between energy production and consumption and the impact it has on the cleanliness and health of the air we breathe, including pollutants released from energy sources.

concepts.title: land use planning
concepts.body: Land use planning is the process of evaluating and designating how land in a specific area should be used, balancing development needs with environmental protection and community interests.

concepts.title: lifecycle ghg emissions
concepts.body: Lifecycle GHG emissions refer to the total greenhouse gas emissions associated with a product or service throughout its entire lifecycle, including extraction of raw materials, production, transportation, use, and disposal.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 1
content.title: Part 1: Renewables and Their Impact on GHG Emissions

content.text: Part 1 Overview

Renewable energy is vital for climate change mitigation because it generates electricity with near-zero GHG emissions during operations. In contrast, fossil fuels such as natural gas and coal release large amounts of carbon dioxide (CO2) and other harmful gases. For example, the IEA estimates that coal-fired power plants emit an average of 865 grams of CO₂ per kilowatt-hour (kWh). Natural gas combustion emits about 389 grams of CO2 per kWh of electricity. By comparison, wind and solar power generate only 13 and 43 grams of CO2 per kWh, respectively. These numbers show the potential of renewable energy in reducing emissions.
Lifecycle Emissions

The lifecycle of energy production includes all stages from raw material extraction to energy conversion, distribution, usage, and eventual waste management or decommissioning. This process accounts for environmental, economic, and social impacts at each phase. When looking at the entire lifecycle of energy production, renewable sources still have a significant edge. The emissions from solar and wind energy are much lower than those from coal and natural gas. For instance, coal and natural gas have lifecycle emissions of 1,001 and 486 grams of CO2 per kWh, while solar and wind technology have far less, with wind associated with 13 grams and solar associated with 43 grams of CO2 per kWh of energy they generate, primarily due to manufacturing and construction. These factors make renewables valuable for governments, non-state actors and businesses alike to decarbonize and reduce their exposure to climate risks.

content.title: Part 2:Economic and Health Benefits of Renewables

content.text: Part 2 Overview

Renewable energy also brings substantial economic benefits. One way to measure this is by considering the "social cost of carbon". The social cost of carbon (SCC) represents the estimated economic damage caused by each ton of CO2 emitted, including costs related to health impacts, climate disasters, agricultural losses, and economic disruptions. A 2022 study recalculated the SCC at $185 per ton of CO2, significantly higher than previous estimates. This figure was determined using updated climate-economic models that factor in more severe and long-term effects of climate change. By reducing emissions, renewable energy helps mitigate these costs, providing both environmental and economic benefits. By reducing emissions, renewables help lower the cost of carbon to society.

In addition to reducing GHG emissions, renewable energy contributes to improved air quality. The combustion of fossil fuels for electricity generation emits harmful pollutants such as sulfur oxides (SOx), nitrogen oxides (NOx), particulate matter, carbon monoxide, and volatile organic compounds (VOCs). These pollutants are linked to various health problems, including respiratory diseases and heart conditions. For example, natural gas combustion produces an average of 7.6 pounds of particulate matter emissions and 0.6 pounds of sulfur dioxide emissions per million standard cubic feet of natural gas combusted. The World Health Organization (WHO) has estimated that outdoor air pollution causes around 4.2 million premature deaths annually, primarily from diseases such as stroke, heart disease, lung cancer, and respiratory infections. In contrast, renewable energy systems generate virtually no air pollution during operation, with emissions occurring mainly during their construction, manufacturing, and transportation.

Similarly, clean cooking is key to addressing indoor air pollution, as seen in Module 2 on Energy Access. Traditional biomass and kerosene use release black carbon, a major contributor to indoor air pollution and severe respiratory illnesses, particularly in low-income households. Transitioning to cleaner energy sources for both electricity and cooking can significantly improve public health and reduce environmental harm.

The air quality benefits of renewable energy are clear. If the world adopts renewable energy and limits global warming to 1.5°C, air pollutant emissions in 2050 could fall by up to 90% compared to 2022 levels. Similarly, global premature deaths and disabilities could go down by 86% in 2025 compared to 2022. This would prevent up to 5.13 million excess deaths annually, according to a 2023 study. This reduction in pollution would have a significant impact on public health. Like with GHG emissions, renewable energy generates economic value by reducing air pollutant emissions and its associated economic costs.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3
content.title: Part 3: Water Use and Quality

content.text: Water use is another important issue when it comes to energy generation. Most energy systems rely on water for cooling and steam production. In 2021, global energy generation used about 370 billion cubic meters of freshwater, equating to 10% of worldwide freshwater withdrawals. Fossil fuel power plants were responsible for a large portion of this water use. Coal plants alone withdrew 189.6 billion cubic meters of water. In contrast, renewable energy technologies used just 12.1 billion cubic meters in 2021. As such, solar panels and wind turbines do not require water for cooling or steam production, using it only for cleaning and construction, significantly reducing overall water consumption. However, geothermal energy does require water as a heat transfer fluid in the form of steam or hot water to generate electricity or provide direct heating, making its water use higher than other renewables.

Renewable energy also benefits water quality. Fossil fuel power plants often discharge harmful pollutants like arsenic, mercury, and lead into nearby water bodies, even after wastewater treatment. A 2020 study estimated that, if renewables make up 85% of global energy by 2050, energy-generated freshwater eutrophication (overaccumulation of nutrients in water) would be ten times lower than in a scenario where renewables only comprise 20% of global energy. Marine eutrophication, another major environmental issue, would also be reduced by 3.5 times.

content.intro: M6: The Climate Change-Energy Nexus | Chapter 2 | Lesson 1 | Part 3 | Case Study
content.title: Case Study: Iraq

content.text: Case StudyRBAS: Climate Action for Human Security

In the Arab region, particularly Iraq, climate change poses an existential threat to returning Internally Displaced Persons (IDP) by forcing men to seek urban employment, fracturing family and social networks. Rising temperatures and reduced water flow will exacerbate water scarcity, pollution, disasters, and public health issues, worsening societal disruptions and livelihood uncertainty in already fragile communities. The Climate Action for Human Security project in Al Hawizeh Marshland in Iraq was undertaken to address this issue. The program was led by the UNDP jointly with the Ministry of Health and Environment and the local government in Missan and funded through a grant of $922,000 from the SDG Climate Facility regional project.

This initiative addresses severe environmental degradation and socio-economic challenges exacerbated by climate change. Focusing on enhancing climate security, specific goals included the deployment of innovative clean drinking water supply systems, support for economic diversification through ecotourism, and the empowerment of women in local communities. The project achieved several key outcomes, including the installation of 15 off-grid solar PV systems for drinking water purification, directly benefiting at least 1,500 people. Additionally, the construction of 6 ecotourism facilities benefited 128 households and reduced displacement pressures. A gender-responsive train-the-trainers program on solar PV energy systems was also developed, benefiting at least 1,000 people, 50% of whom were women, through training and awareness-raising initiatives.

The project’s implementation strategy supported crisis-affected communities in three ways. First, innovative solar PV water purification systems and constructed wetlands for wastewater management were deployed to address acute drinking water scarcity and poor sanitation in the marshlands. Second, ecotourism facilities were constructed to provide alternative income sources and enhance social cohesion. These facilities included guest houses, markets for local crafts, and wildlife observation towers. Thirdly, extensive training programs were conducted to enhance local capacity in managing the new systems and promoting sustainable ecotourism practices. Special focus was placed on empowering women through targeted training and involvement in local cooperatives.

Sustainability is a core focus of the project, with long-term plans for local municipalities to manage water systems and community cooperatives to handle maintenance costs. Equipment utilized for the project water supply system will become governmental assets to ensure working performance, while ecotourism facilities will be owned by local community beneficiaries with an elected local committee to look after the operation and maintenance of these facilities15. This can scale up and expand the reach of the project to more communities, enhancing infrastructure, and continuing to build local capacities to adapt to climate changes. This case study demonstrates the power of integrating renewable energy, water management, and socio-economic development to address the complex challenges of climate change. By harmonizing these elements, the project has not only met immediate needs but also laid the foundation for long-term environmental sustainability and socio-economic stability in the region.

content.title: Learning Objectives
content.intro: If you only have space to remember 3 things:

objectives.title: Renewables are Essential for Achieving Global Climate Targets.
objectives.description: Unlike fossil fuels, renewables such as wind and solar produce minimal lifecycle emissions, making them essential for achieving global climate targets, including the commitment made at COP28 to triple renewable capacity by 2030.

objectives.title: Renewable Energy Enhances Public Health and Economic Value.
objectives.description: By reducing air pollution, renewable energy helps prevent millions of premature deaths and lowers healthcare costs. Additionally, cutting carbon emissions decreases the social cost of carbon, providing significant economic value.

objectives.title: Sustainable Energy Transition Supports Water Conservation and Quality.
objectives.description: Renewable energy requires far less water than fossil fuel-based power generation, reducing water consumption and pollution. A transition to 85% renewables by 2050 could significantly decrease freshwater and marine eutrophication, improving overall water quality.
